captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
-Hey, guys.
It's Brooklyn and Bailey.

And today we're going
to be showing you

how to make your own
DIY graphic T-shirts.

-And you guys may notice
that we are sitting

on the floor with
our couch behind us.

That is because we are
redoing our studio.

Hopefully we will finish the
studio soon, in a few months
or so.

And we can put up
a new studio tour.
And you all can see it.
It's pretty cute.

The little bit that we've gotten
done so far is really cute,a

and we're actually
really excited.
So graphic T-shirts.

Let's go back to
the craft tutorial.

-The supplies you will
need are some fabric paint,

a basic paintbrush,
and X-Acto knife,

a pencil, a stencil
of your choice,

a blow dryer and iron, some
freezer paper, and a T-shirt.

-To begin you're going to take
the stencil that you printed

out-- yes, those ones--
and place it on the table.

Then take your section
of freezer paper

and place it on
top of the stencil

so that you can see
the stencil through it.

And then you trace your
stencil onto the freezer paper.

Go ahead and put some cardboard
underneath your freezer paper

once you've finished
drawing your stencil.

Next, take your X-Acto knife
and trace the longer lines
that you have drawn.

So basically you're
cutting out any pieces

that you want to be
colored onto your T-shirt.

When you're done cutting
out your stencil,

place it on your T-shirt where
you want it to be painted on.

Next, take your iron-- yes,
and wave it around-- and start

ironing your stencil
onto your T-shirt

And if you're wondering what
in the world we're doing,

we like to call
this the iron dance.

Once you have finished
ironing on your stencil,

go ahead and take your
fabric paints and paint away.
Be creative.

Use your colors and
paint that stencil.

As a precaution make
sure you have a paper

or a piece of cardboard
in between the two layers

of your T-shirt so the
paint does not leak through.

When you're done
painting the stencil,

use the blow dryer to dry the
paint, or your sister's face.

Once your paint
is completely dry,

go ahead and carefully peel
off your freezer paper.

There you have your
DIY graphic T-shirts.

Thank you guys so much
for watching this video.

If you want to see your
recreation featured in one

of our next videos, then be
sure to tweet us a picture
of your graphic T-shirt using--
--the hashtag BBGraphicTee.

And obviously if you're
hash tagging your photo

with this hashtag-- I
guess-- you are giving us

permission to use it
in one of our videos.

So we will pick a few and
feature them in our next video.

-And I think that's
all for today,
So we'll see you guys next week.
Bye.
-One, two, three, go.
[GROWL]
-Oh.
Um--
-Volume-ous enough for you?
-Voluminous.
-Volume-ous.
-It's voluminous.
-Volume-ous.
-We discussed this days ago.
It is voluminous.
Not volume-ous.
-Volume is like--

-This is getting
better and better.
--amount of-- wait.
Is at the amount of like,
-I don't know.
--space an object takes up.
-Ask the wise gnome.
I look like a gnome.

title: DIY Graphic T-Shirts | Brooklyn and Bailey
